# Introduction

This file contains all of the script necessary to load and clean the raw data, transform/rescale variables, and generate whatever additional measures are necessary to run our final models. 

Notes:

1. We use the 2018, 2019, and 2020 values for trade, GDP, population, and V-Dem scores. Updated on 2021-07-17. 
2. There were excess observations (about 200) resulting from merges that only contained country variables. Dropped these 2021-10-15


## Public opinion data setup

# Create list for base location data 
base.list <- list()
file.names <- list.files(here::here("../Geographic files/Base locations"), pattern = ".csv", full.names = TRUE)
base.list <- lapply(file.names, read_csv)

# Create list of map files
map.list <- list()
province.list <- list()

map.list[[1]]  <- raster::getData("GADM", country = "AUS", level = 1)
map.list[[2]]  <- raster::getData("GADM", country = "BEL", level = 2)
map.list[[3]]  <- raster::getData("GADM", country = "DEU", level = 1)
map.list[[4]]  <- raster::getData("GADM", country = "ITA", level = 1)
map.list[[5]]  <- readOGR(here::here("../Military Spending/Shapefiles/japanpolygonChubu Region_AL375/Chubu Region_AL3.shp"))
map.list[[6]]  <- raster::getData("GADM", country = "KWT", level = 1)
map.list[[7]]  <- raster::getData("GADM", country = "NLD", level = 1)
map.list[[8]]  <- raster::getData("GADM", country = "PHL", level = 1)
map.list[[9]]  <- raster::getData("GADM", country = "POL", level = 1)
map.list[[10]] <- raster::getData("GADM", country = "PRT", level = 1)
map.list[[11]] <- readOGR(here::here("../Military Spending/Shapefiles/Korea regions/Korea-regions.shp"))
map.list[[12]] <- raster::getData("GADM", country = "ESP", level = 1)
map.list[[13]] <- raster::getData("GADM", country = "TUR", level = 1)
map.list[[14]] <- readOGR(here::here("../Military Spending/Shapefiles/UK regions/UK-regions.shp"))

# Create empty lists for point in poly output and final data frame output
point.list <- list()
final.list <- list()

# Process the base data for the point in poly procedure
# Remove missing values from South Korea data frame and apply coordinates to the base location lists
# Have to run England separately, so it's embedded in an if-else statement
for (i in 1:14){

if (i < 14) {
  base.list[[i]] <- as.data.frame(base.list[[i]])
  base.list[[i]] <- dplyr::filter(base.list[[i]], !is.na(base.list[[i]]$Latitude))
  sp::coordinates(base.list[[i]]) <- c("Longitude", "Latitude")
  as(base.list[[i]], "SpatialPoints")
  proj4string(base.list[[i]]) <- CRS("+proj=longlat +datum=WGS84")
  proj4string(base.list[[i]]) <- proj4string(map.list[[i]])
  point.list[[i]] <- sp::over(base.list[[i]], map.list[[i]])
  final.list[[i]] <- cbind(base.list[[i]]@data, base.list[[i]]@coords, point.list[[i]])
}
  else {
  map.list[[i]] <- spTransform(map.list[[i]], CRS("+proj=longlat +datum=WGS84"))
  sp::coordinates(base.list[[i]]) <- c("Longitude", "Latitude")
  as(base.list[[i]], "SpatialPoints")
  proj4string(base.list[[i]]) <- CRS("+proj=longlat +datum=WGS84")
  proj4string(base.list[[i]]) <- proj4string(map.list[[i]])
  point.list[[i]] <- sp::over(base.list[[i]], map.list[[i]])
  final.list[[i]] <- cbind(base.list[[i]]@data, base.list[[i]]@coords, point.list[[i]])
  }
}

# First reading in CPI data for all urban consumers and converting 2011 to base year to match PWT data.
cpi <- tq_get("CPIAUCSL", 
              get = "economic.data",
              from = "2010-01-01",
              to = "2019-01-01") %>% 
  mutate(year = format(date, "%Y")) %>% 
  group_by(year) %>% 
  dplyr::summarise(cpi = mean(price)) %>% 
  mutate(basevalue = cpi[year==2011], # Set new base year value of 2011 to put GDP values on same scale
         cpi = cpi/basevalue,
         year = as.numeric(year)) %>% 
  filter(year == 2018)


# WARNING!!! for whatever reason the pivot function sometimes doesn't work on every other pass. 
# Make sure this is in long form

# Also, LOTS of stupid names match the Netherlands country codes. Filter those out.
netherlandsfilter <- c("Curaçao, Kingdom of the Netherlands", "Sint Maarten, Kingdom of the Netherlands", "Aruba, Kingdom of the Netherlands")

`%notin%` <- Negate(`%in%`) # create this to get rid of lots of duplicate Netherlands values. Appear as a result of protectorates or territories. 

imf.imp <- readxl::read_xlsx(here::here("Raw Data/Exports_and_Imports_by_Areas_and_Co (4).xlsx"), sheet = 2, skip = 5)
imf.exp <- readxl::read_xlsx(here::here("Raw Data/Exports_and_Imports_by_Areas_and_Co (4).xlsx"), sheet = 1, skip = 5)

# Survey run dates
# Wave 1: 2018-09 through 2018-11
# Wave 2: 2019-07 through 2019-08
# Wave 3: 2020-04 through 2020-05


imf.exp.long <- imf.exp %>% 
  dplyr::rename("country" = 1) %>% 
  mutate(ccode = countrycode::countrycode(country, "country.name", "cown")) %>% 
  filter(ccode %in% ccode.list) %>% 
  slice(-c(8, 16:18)) %>% 
  pivot_longer(cols = 2:49,
               values_to = "us_exports_to_partner",
               names_to = "year") %>% 
  separate(year, into = c("year", "month"), sep = "M") %>% 
  mutate(year = as.numeric(year),
         month = as.numeric(month),
         date = glue::glue("{year}","-","{month}","-","1"),
         date = as.Date(date, "%Y-%m-%d"),
         trade.2018 = case_when(
           date < "2018-09-01" & date >= "2017-09-01" ~ us_exports_to_partner,
         ),
         trade.2019 = case_when(
           date < "2019-07-01" & date >= "2018-07-01" ~ us_exports_to_partner,
         ),
         trade.2020 = case_when(
           date < "2020-04-01" & date >= "2019-04-01" ~ us_exports_to_partner,
         )) %>% 
  group_by(country, ccode) %>% 
  dplyr::summarise(trade.2018 = sum(trade.2018, na.rm = TRUE),
                   trade.2019 = sum(trade.2019, na.rm = TRUE),
                   trade.2020 = sum(trade.2020, na.rm = TRUE)) %>% 
  pivot_longer(cols = starts_with("trade"),
               values_to = "us_exports_to_partner",
               names_to = "year") %>% 
  mutate(year = case_when(
    year == "trade.2018" ~ 2018,
    year == "trade.2019" ~ 2019,
    year == "trade.2020" ~ 2020
  ))



imf.imp.long <- imf.imp %>% 
  dplyr::rename("country" = 1) %>% 
  mutate(ccode = countrycode::countrycode(country, "country.name", "cown")) %>% 
  filter(ccode %in% ccode.list) %>% 
  slice(-c(8, 16:18)) %>% 
  pivot_longer(cols = 2:49,
               values_to = "us_imports_from_partner",
               names_to = "year") %>% 
  separate(year, into = c("year", "month"), sep = "M") %>% 
  mutate(year = as.numeric(year),
         month = as.numeric(month),
         date = glue::glue("{year}","-","{month}","-","1"),
         date = as.Date(date, "%Y-%m-%d"),
         trade.2018 = case_when(
           date < "2018-09-01" & date >= "2017-09-01" ~ us_imports_from_partner,
         ),
         trade.2019 = case_when(
           date < "2019-07-01" & date >= "2018-07-01" ~ us_imports_from_partner,
         ),
         trade.2020 = case_when(
           date < "2020-04-01" & date >= "2019-04-01" ~ us_imports_from_partner,
         )) %>% 
  group_by(country, ccode) %>% 
  dplyr::summarise(trade.2018 = sum(trade.2018, na.rm = TRUE),
                   trade.2019 = sum(trade.2019, na.rm = TRUE),
                   trade.2020 = sum(trade.2020, na.rm = TRUE)) %>% 
  pivot_longer(cols = starts_with("trade"),
               values_to = "us_imports_from_partner",
               names_to = "year") %>% 
  mutate(year = case_when(
    year == "trade.2018" ~ 2018,
    year == "trade.2019" ~ 2019,
    year == "trade.2020" ~ 2020
  ))
